title: Balaclavas Are This Winter’s Most Stylish Accessory
description: A fashion trend that’s actually practical.
excerpt: Balaclavas are officially trending this winter, and if you're wondering where to pick up your own, we found 15 great options for every style and budget.

html:
The Crochet One

Sandy Liang Kady Balaclava

Fans of Sandy Liang will recognize the designer’s hallmarks in this wool-blend piece, including a dainty bow and frilly crochet trim. One fun bonus is the inclusion of a ponytail hole in the back; flat hat hair, no more.

The Cable Knit One

Guest in Residence Cable Knit Cashmere Balaclava

Direct from Gigi Hadid’s cashmere brand comes this icy blue balaclava, which is made from a combination of wool and cashmere that’s truly insulating. It also comes in a fire-truck red.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

The Minimalist One

Paloma Wool Ribbed Balaclava

Prefer to keep your winter accessories simple? Paloma Wool’s terracotta design is completely unadorned, save for some pretty button detailing at the back. The sleek silhouette should be easy to tuck into coats or under bulky scarves.

The 3D Floral One

Molly Goddard Wanda Balaclava

Or, use your balaclava to add pizzazz to an otherwise standard ensemble: Molly Goddard makes one from mohair that’s decked out with a sizeable floral appliqué at the collar.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

The Pointelle One

Damson Madder Pointelle Hood

Try a two-tone accent with Damson Madder’s delicate pointelle hood, which is made from 100 percent recycled polyester.

The Bonnet One

Straw x Herd Claret Bonnet

There’s something charmingly retro about a bonnet, and this one—made from thick plant-dyed wool in a bold wine hue—serves as a polished finishing touch to any outfit.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

The Budget-Friendly One

Organic Basics Soft Knit Balaclava

If your priorities are practicality and budget, look no further than Organic Basics’ pared-back piece. It comes in three colors in an unfussy, ribbed design.

The Polka Dot One

Chloé Cabochon Knit Balaclava

Dotted with tiny gold studs for a 3D patterned effect, Chloé’s merino wool piece can be worn three ways, as a balaclava, a neck warmer, or a hood. Take your pick, depending on the temperature.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

The Butter Yellow One

Nanushka Filco Cashmere Balaclava

Butter yellow is our go-to hue for a soft bit of color that won’t overpower a neutral outfit. Nanushka’s soft cashmere hood features a twisty knit pattern.

The Seriously Luxe One

The Row Danylo Balaclava

If you’re going to invest in a designer balaclava, it may as well be from The Row. Here, pure Italian-made merino wool combines with an extra-long silhouette (it doubles as a dickey) for one option that’s guaranteed to keep you warm.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

The Frilly One

Shushu/Tong Cape Balaclava

Ruffles and an appliqué bow team up for an ultra-feminine piece. But, aesthetics aside, the tighter fit here around the head and neck will trap heat better than a looser style.

The Textured One

COS Textured Cashmere Balaclava

Equipped with a drawstring for an adjustable fit, this fuzzy cashmere hood feels extra-cozy.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

The Tomato Red One

ARCH4 Klosters Ribbed Cashmere Balaclava

We found the antidote to sad winter weather, and it’s this punchy red cashmere balaclava. It’s Little Red Riding Hood without the wolf drama.

The Colorblocked One

Marni Colorblock Balaclava

Marni’s colorblock balaclava is perfect for the indecisive dresser; it’s punctuated by intricate blanket stitching—a tiny detail that makes the bold two-tone design less severe.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

The High-Contrast One

Ganni Cashmere Mix Balaclava

Stand out from the crowd in a graphic cashmere knit from Danish brand Ganni. It has three ties up the neck, which both help make it adjustable and pull the whole thing together (no pun intended).
